channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Trial started for vaccine against one of the scariest coronavirus variants
item.description: The vaccine is being developed “out of an abundance of caution,” Fauci says.

item.title: HoloLens for 120,000 Army personnel: Microsoft inks $21.9 billion deal
item.description: Was originally pegged at $480 million in 2018, follows scrutiny over other DOD deals.

item.title: Apple commits to build “grid-scale” energy storage in California
item.description: 110 of Apple’s manufacturing partners are moving to 100 percent renewable energy.

item.title: Ubiquiti breach puts countless cloud-based devices at risk of takeover
item.description: Report: Theft of crypto secrets could allow hackers to remotely log in to devices.

item.title: Xiaomi’s first foldable features a liquid camera lens, Samsung-style design
item.description: The Xiaomi Mi Mix Fold jumps into the foldable wars.

item.title: Biden broadband plan will be hated by big ISPs, welcomed by Internet users
item.description: Biden wants to end hidden fees and fund municipal and nonprofit networks.

item.title: Mercedes-AMG shows off its new F1-based road car hybrid system
item.description: After dominating F1 for 7 seasons, company ready to transfer tech to the street.

item.title: CDPR puts off planned multiplayer Cyberpunk game amid restructuring
item.description: Online features will come to future CDPR releases “when it makes sense,” though.

item.title: Biden plan eliminates billions in fossil fuel subsidies
item.description: Fossil fuel industry gets up to $62 billion in handouts every year.

item.title: Teens fully protected by Pfizer’s COVID-19 vaccine, company says
item.description: Vaccinated adolescents had higher levels of neutralizing antibodies than older groups.

item.title: Godzilla vs. Kong review: Kaiju greatness that lives up to its absurd title
item.description: Two beasts enter. Two beasts fight. And audiences finally have reasons to roar.

item.title: Containerize all the things! Arm v9 takes security seriously
item.description: Intel and AMD will need to keep an eye on Arm competition in their strongholds.

item.title: How to achieve smart home nirvana (or, home automation without subscription)
item.description: With some work and planning, Home Assistant sets your smart home.

item.title: Rick and Morty fans won’t have long to wait for S5 as Adult Swim drops trailer
item.description: “Police? A strange, horny ocean man is on my lawn.”

item.title: Android sends 20x more data to Google than iOS sends to Apple, study says
item.description: Google contests the estimate, saying it’s based on flawed methodology.

item.title: Biden administration launches big push for offshore wind
item.description: Big cross-agency effort will set the stage for massive growth by 2050.

item.title: PSA: You have one day until Nintendo delists Super Mario 3D All-Stars
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Amazon tablets, Apple Macs, and Dell monitors.

item.title: Star Wars: The Bad Batch trailer arrives ahead of May the Fourth launch
item.description: Today’s trailer follows massive cast announcement for Disney+’s Obi-Wan.

item.title: Police say they found mafia fugitive on YouTube, posting cooking tutorials
item.description: Fugitive hid face on cooking videos but was IDed by his tattoos, reports say.

item.title: Apple will reveal the next versions of iOS, macOS at WWDC21, starting June 7
item.description: It will be entirely online again, as expected.

item.title: Nike sues over “Satan Shoe,” disavowing all connection to soul soles
item.description: Nike really doesn’t like anyone thinking it made or endorses the Satan Shoe.

item.title: Google Maps gets AR indoor navigation, new eco-friendly route options
item.description: Google details a ton of new features coming to Google Maps.

item.title: “Natural capital” accounting method might give nature an economic voice
item.description: UN adopts way of putting a dollar amount on nature, but some question the idea.

item.title: Pre-Columbian people in the Atacama raised parrots for their feathers
item.description: Llama caravans probably transported live parrots hundreds of kilometers.

item.title: Sega forces mistaken DMCA takedown for Steam data tracker
item.description: Yakuza: Like a Dragon info page misidentified as pirate site.

item.title: Amazon tweets trolling Congress were so bad that IT thought account was hacked
item.description: Support ticket noted “suspicious activity on @amazonnews Twitter account.”

item.title: Porsche will start testing a lower-carbon biofuel in racing
item.description: ExxonMobil and Porsche are starting with biofuel, moving to synthetic fuel soon.

item.title: SpaceX loses another Starship prototype as landing sequence fails
item.description: This was the company’s fourth attempt to land a full-size Starship.

item.title: Intel 11th-generation Rocket Lake-S gaming CPUs did not impress us
item.description: Rocket Lake-S doesn’t look like a very compelling gen-on-gen upgrade.

item.title: VW changing to Voltswagen—early April fool or corporate rebranding? [Updated]
item.description: VW posted, then deleted, a press release announcing name change, according to CNBC.

item.title: SpaceX working toward early Tuesday morning Starship launch [Updated]
item.description: This rocket rolled to the launch pad less than three weeks ago.

item.title: Apple-funded Stanford study concludes Apple Watch can be used to measure frailty
item.description: Study contributes to Apple’s messaging about the Watch’s impact on health care.

item.title: Smartphones are finally matching 2012’s Nokia 808 in camera sensor size
item.description: It’s got a rear screen, ceramic body, and a really big camera bump.

item.title: Parler: We warned the FBI more than 50 times before the Capitol riot
item.description: Company claims it warned FBI about violent posts before everything hit the fan.

item.title: AT&T lobbies against nationwide fiber, says 10Mbps uploads are good enough
item.description: AT�T admits fiber is most “future-proof” but wants US to fund slower networks.

item.title: Hackers backdoor PHP source code after breaching internal git server
item.description: Code gave code-execution powers to anyone who knew the secret password: “zerodium.”

item.title: Sony will shut down online stores for legacy PlayStation games this summer
item.description: You’ll still be able to re-download old purchases—but not make new ones.

item.title: Red Hat withdraws from the Free Software Foundation after Stallman’s return
item.description: Corporate sponsors and board members alike are retreating from RMS-gate.

item.title: Sweeping climate law zeroes out carbon pollution for Massachusetts
item.description: State will track progress across the entire economy for the next 30 years.

item.title: Iron Age warriors were laid to rest on fluffy down pillows
item.description: One warrior was also buried with a decapitated eagle-owl.

item.title: The massive cargo ship that blocked the Suez Canal is now moving again
item.description: After impeding traffic for days, high tide and plenty of tugs got it unstuck.

item.title: Hop on COVID-19’s most famous ship—the Diamond Princess—in HBO’s The Last Cruise
item.description: A staffer sums it up (before knowing the damage): “The walking dead, a dystopian situation.”

item.title: Ars Technica’s non-fungible guide to NFTs
item.description: Is blockchain item authentication a speculative fad or a technological sea change?

item.title: Meet Boston Dynamics’ next commercial robot, Stretch
item.description: It can unload trucks, build pallets, and will fit anywhere a pallet fits.

item.title: Activision releases online-only PC game without online content, cracked in one day
item.description: Game’s console versions don’t require online connection; all lack online content.

item.title: A light show for every crit: How good are the $39 Pixels “smart” dice?
item.description: Pros: Fully customizable, super trippy. Cons: The usual Kickstarter small-team caveats.

item.title: Bus drivers bring adaptation of Alien to London’s West End in Alien on Stage
item.description: SXSW documentary captures ordinary people daring something truly extraordinary.

item.title: The ionizer in your kid’s school may not do much to fight COVID
item.description: Claims they remove 99% of viruses are unproven; cheaper air filters are more effective.

item.title: Vaccine FOMO is real. Here’s how to deal with it
item.description: The waiting is the hardest part—but there are steps you can take to manage the anxiety.

item.title: Can you make a comedy set during COVID-19? Recovery takes the idea for a drive
item.description: Director: “I want people thinking it’s a Marvel movie. And that Timothee Chalamet is in it.”

item.title: “Are schools safe?” is the wrong question to be asking
item.description: There’s no right answer on school safety, just a right answer for each community.

item.title: What will it take to get a giant cargo ship unstuck from the Suez Canal?
item.description: Tugboats, excavators, and cranes all may be enlisted to help the Ever Given.
